Universal Access to Information: If the internet became a basic human right, it would ensure that everyone, regardless of their socio-economic status, has access to the vast amount of information available online. This would lead to a more informed and educated population, as well as a greater understanding of different cultures and perspectives.

Global Connectivity: The internet would bring people from all over the world closer together, allowing for more effective communication and collaboration. This would have a profound impact on international relations, as well as on the way businesses operate.

Digital Citizenship: With the internet as a basic human right, there would be a greater emphasis on digital citizenship education. This would teach people how to use the internet responsibly, protect their privacy, and navigate the online world safely.

Increased Political Participation: The internet would give people a greater voice in the political process, allowing them to participate in debates, organize protests, and hold their governments accountable. This could lead to more democratic societies and greater political stability.

Economic Growth: The internet would provide a level playing field for businesses of all sizes, allowing them to reach a global audience and compete on a more equal footing. This would lead to increased economic growth and job creation, as well as greater innovation and entrepreneurship.
